s.text: If we in the United States are the good guys more than half (or even half) the time, a strong WTO is in our interest.
If the WTO proves powerless in its first big case, all will observe that its rules are only binding when the strong wish them to be.
A strong WTO will block a lot of measures that hurt the U.S. economy in the long run, if it is allowed to gain strength and authority.
It also instructs them about how things can be different from what they are in today's China--where all power resides in the bloody hands of a narrow oligarchy and a broader party of bootlickers.
But tariff-loving senators killed the WTO in the late 1940s.
But tariff-loving senators killed the WTO in the late 1940s.

But the United States' different principles for trade with Cuba are about to cause it trouble, thanks to the World Trade Organization--the newly established referee to police international trade disputes that Clinton was so proud to establish (and Congress to vote for) at the end of 1994.

China's leaders have drawn conclusions from the collapse of the Soviet Union: that if they allow dissent or take steps toward democracy, they will be dead or jailed in a decade; and that no amount of economic benefit is worth the destruction of their regime.

It keeps other countries from breaking trade commitments that benefit the United States in exchange for keeping the United States from breaking trade commitments that benefit those countries, and it keeps all of us from indulging in the everyone-loses pattern of trade sanction and retaliation.
